title-group.article-title: Childhood Metabolic Biomarkers Are Associated with Performance on Cognitive Tasks in Young Children

article-meta.aff: 1:Department of Psychiatry, School of Medicine, University of Colorado at Anschutz (CU Anschutz);
3:Department of Epidemiology, Colorado School of Public Health, CU-Anschutz;
4:Research Service, Denver Veteran’s Administration Medical Center;
5:Lifecourse Epidemiology of Adiposity and Diabetes (LEAD) Center, CU-Anschutz

author-notes.corresp: Address correspondence to: Allison L. B. Shapiro, MPH, PhD; Department of Psychiatry, School of Medicine, University of Colorado at Anschutz; Campus Box F546; 13001 East 17th Ave, Aurora, CO, 80045; allison.shapiro@ucdenver.edu

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: To evaluate the hypothesis that metabolic measures (fasting glucose, insulin and Homeostatic Model of Assessment for Insulin Resistance [HOMA-IR] levels) are inversely associated with performance on cognitive tasks using data from young (4- to 6-year-old), typically developing, healthy children.

sec.title: Study design:
sec.p: Data were obtained from children participating in the Healthy Start study, a pre-birth cohort in Colorado. HOMA-IR, glucose and insulin values were centered and scaled using the study sample means and standard deviations (SD). Thus, they are reported in number of SD units from the mean. Fully corrected T-scores for inhibitory control (Flanker task), cognitive flexibility (Dimensional Change Card Sort test), and receptive language (Picture Vocabulary test) were obtained via the NIH Toolbox cognition battery.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Children included in this analysis (n = 137) were 4.6 years-old, on average. Per 1 SD unit, fasting glucose (B = - 2.02, 95% CI: −3.54, −0.49), insulin (B = −1.67, 95% CI: −2.96, - 0.38), and HOMA-IR values (B = −1.79, 95% CI: −3.09, −0.49) were each significantly and inversely associated with inhibitory control (P < .05 for all, respectively). Fasting glucose levels were also inversely associated with cognitive flexibility (B = −1.96, 95% CI: −3.71, −0.21, p = 0.03).

sec.title: Conclusion(s):
sec.p: Our data suggest that metabolic health may impact fluid cognitive function in healthy, young children.
